Words.definition: To soothe or pacify
Words.exampleSentence: The burglar tried to placate the snarling dog by referring to it as a 'Nice Doggy' and offering it a treat.

Words.definition: Sharp and irritating to the senses
Words.exampleSentence: The smoke from the burning tires was extremely pungent.

Words.definition: Intended to delay
Words.exampleSentence: Dilator's massive shield was built for diltory tactics during escapes.

Words.definition: To depart clandestinely; to steal off and hide
Words.exampleSentence: The rouge in the party absconded with the loot while the party was fighting the boss monster.

Words.definition: Deviating from the norm
Words.exampleSentence: Smite's Abberrant Camera View sets it apart from other MOBA titles.

Words.definition: Eager and enthusiastic willingness.
Words.exampleSentence: The bloodthirsty warrior charged into battle with grand alacrity.

Words.definition: Deviation from the normal order, form, or rule; abnormality
Words.exampleSentence: Snow during a hurricane is considered an weather anomaly.

Words.definition: An expression of approval or praise
Words.exampleSentence: The highest approbation British royalty can give a person is knighthood.

Words.definition: Strenuous, taxing; requiring signifigant effort
Words.exampleSentence: Taking the GRE's is an arduous undertaking.

Words.definition: To ease or lessen; to appease or pacify
Words.exampleSentence: The mother coos to her baby to assuage his tantrum.

Words.definition: Daring and fearless; recklessly bold
Words.exampleSentence: The audacious mouse was found in a mouse trap in the kitchen.

Words.definition: Without adornment; bare; severley simple; ascetic
Words.exampleSentence: A game prototype is usually aesthetically austere.

Words.definition: Taken as a given; possessing self-evident truth
Words.exampleSentence: It's axeomatic that the AXE-o-Matic will cut the time chopping down trees in half!

Words.definition: Following or in agreement with accepted, traditional standards
Words.exampleSentence: Korrasami fans became estatic when their O.T.P. became a canonical relationship.

Words.definition: Inclined to change one's mind impulsively; erratic, unpredictable
Words.exampleSentence: Mugen's capricious attitude leads to both friend and foe getting caught off guard.

Words.definition: To criticize severely; to officially rebuke
Words.exampleSentence: Justice Scalia's displayed his censure of the liberal Justices during the Gay Rights case.

Words.definition: Trickery or subterfuge
Words.exampleSentence: Usually, it's Joseph Joestar's chicanery that helps him defeat stronger opponents.

Words.definition: An informed and astute judge in matters of taste; expert
Words.exampleSentence: TotalBiscuit is considered a connoisseur of video games

Words.definition: Complex or complicated
Words.exampleSentence: The game system of the Making History series can come across as convoluted, as the game simulates all functions of every nation.

Words.definition: To undeceive; to set right
Words.exampleSentence: It's up to parents to decide when they will disabuse their children of the existance of the tooth fairy.

Words.definition: Conflicting; dissonant or harsh in sound
Words.exampleSentence: The middle school band instructor backed out of doing Lord of the Rings due to the discordent ensemble.

Words.definition: Fundamentally distinct or dissimilar
Words.exampleSentence: Artemis's controls and goals are disparate for each player.

Words.definition: Extreme boldness; presumptuousness
Words.exampleSentence: Given current events, those who say "All Lives Matter" display their effrontery more than their support.

Words.definition: Well-spoken, expressive, articulate
Words.exampleSentence: The eloquent instructor received high reviews due to his clear instructions.

Words.definition: To weaken; to reduce in vitality
Words.exampleSentence: Working at a dead-end job really enervated his soul.

Words.definition: Dissatisfaction and restlessness resulting from bordom or apathy.
Words.exampleSentence: Now that he can beat everyone with one punch, Saitama's ennui was clear to see in fights.

Words.definition: To use ambiguous language with a deceptive intent
Words.exampleSentence: Most candidates make a lot of promises with equivocal wording on the campaign trail.

Words.definition: Very Learned; scholarly
Words.exampleSentence: The research Stephen Hawking has done throughout his life gives him an Erudite aura.

Words.definition: Exonerate, to clear of blame
Words.exampleSentence: The jury in LA exculpated O.J. Simpson of his crimes

Words.definition: Urgent, pressing; requiring immediate action or attention
Words.exampleSentence: The exigent nature of a child drowning can lead to people to dive in while wearing clothes.

Words.definition: Improvised; done without preperation
Words.exampleSentence: Jenny Matrix's extemporaneous speech on her mother was the result of writing the opening line the night before.

Words.definition: Intentional obstruction, especially using prolonged speechmaking to delay legislative action.
Words.exampleSentence: Wendy Davis wore sneakers when performing her filibuster of the Texas abortion regulations.

Words.definition: To loudly attack or denounce.
Words.exampleSentence: Seeing the boys making fun of the guy caused Dad to fulminate.

Words.definition: artless; frank and candid; lacking in sophistication
Words.exampleSentence: My mother cried when I asked for the address in heaven when I was an ingenuous child.

Words.definition: Accustomed to accepting something undesireable.
Words.exampleSentence: Citizens of war-torn counties have become inured by all the violence surrounding them.

Words.definition: Easily angered; prone to temperamental outbursts
Words.exampleSentence: Metal bat's irascible personality makes him a hero you want to avoid.

Words.definition: To praise highly
Words.exampleSentence: Costco's CEO should be lauded for the low salary ratio between him and his employees.

Words.definition: Clear; easily understood
Words.exampleSentence: A good teacher is lucid while explaining subjects to their students.

Words.definition: The quality of being generously noble in mind and heart, especially in forgiving.
Words.exampleSentence: Pope John Paul II's magnanimity was displayed when he visited his would-be assassin in jail.

Words.definition: Associated with war and the armed forces.
Words.exampleSentence: During times of war, martial law is declared and the military dictatates the rules.

Words.definition: Of the world; typically of or concerned with the ordinary
Words.exampleSentence: Bilbo Baggins wanted to live a mundane life before Gandalf recruited him for his adventure.

Words.definition: Coming into being; in early development stages
Words.exampleSentence: Game protoypes are nascent representations of experiences to come.

Words.definition: Vauge; cloudy; lacking clearly defined form
Words.exampleSentence: When not looking like a human, angels take a nebulous form.

Words.definition: A new word, expression, or usage; the creation or use of new words or senses.
Words.exampleSentence: Jim Sterling created a neologism when he wrote the word Chungus.

Words.definition: Harmful, injurious
Words.exampleSentence: The noxious fumes caused me to hack a lung - literally.

Words.definition: Lacking sharpness of intellect; not clear or precise in thought or expression.
Words.exampleSentence: Brain had to make sure his orders to Pinky worded well or else his obtuse partner would mess them up.

Words.definition: To anticipate to make unnecessary
Words.exampleSentence: The push for cleaner energy obviate the coal mining industry.

Words.definition: Troubling; burdensome
Words.exampleSentence: Having a full-time job while getting a masters leads to an onerous lifestyle.

Words.definition: A song or hymn of praise and thanksgiving.
Words.exampleSentence: Choirs gather together on Sundays to perform paeans to God and Jesus.

Words.definition: A humorous imitation intended for ridicule or comic effect, especially in literature and art.
Words.exampleSentence: Parody is covered under fair use, as it provides critique for an entity.

Words.definition: Recurrent through the year or many years; happening repeatedly.
Words.exampleSentence: Gilligan perennial screw-ups kept the crew on the island for many years.

Words.definition: Intentional breach of faith; treachery.
Words.exampleSentence: Stocking's perfidy at the end of the series came to a surprise to both the characters and the audience.

Words.definition: Cursory; done without care or interest.
Words.exampleSentence: Acadamy Award losers tend to give perfuctory applause towards the oscar winners.

Words.definition: Acutely perceptive; having keen discernment.
Words.exampleSentence: Monk's perspicacious crime-solving skills can be attributed to his OCD.
